Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Situation2: Pre-dawn traffic is sparse and holding patterns are empty.
Story: The phone buzzed just as I settled into my chair, the pre-dawn quiet of the control tower wrapping around me. My friend’s name flashed on the screen. “I think I left my passport at home,” she said, her voice tight with panic. “Can you check and bring it to the airport? My flight’s in two hours.” I glanced at the radar—no holding patterns, no congestion, just a handful of blips moving steadily across the screen. Technically, it was the calmest shift I’d had in weeks. But I knew the expectation: always be vigilant, always be present, even when the sky is empty. My friend needed me—she’d do the same for me, no question. But the responsibility of the airspace pressed on me, the silent demand to stay, to watch, to be ready for anything. My heart thudded as I stared at the phone, torn between the trust of a friend and the duty of the job.
